6.text:
Hallas: To prepare the work for display and
tour the key factor is to stabilise the portrait,

12.text:
undertake minimal conservation treatment and
to glaze and to fit a climate buffered system

18.text:
to the frame itself.
Additional analytical analysis will inform

22.text:
a more long-term conservation care and preventative
conservation programme.

27.text:
Ryder: Infrared reflectography is a very useful
and safe scientific imaging technique that

35.text:
conservators use to gain information about
the painting which is not immediately visible

42.text:
to the naked eye. It's particularly successful
at showing us underdrawing based on carbon

49.text:
and sometimes also compositional changes,
and also damage to the painting.

55.text:
We learnt quite a few very interesting things
in our infrared examinations. One of the things

60.text:
we noticed was that Van Dyck changed the costume.
The collar underneath the white collar that

66.text:
you can see behind me was initially painted
taller and there was also some change at the

72.text:
bottom of the costume on the right-hand side.
Some large dark circular shapes could be seen

78.text:
in the infrared image which was subsequently
covered up with background paint.

84.text:
We also noticed in the infrared image some
dark washes of translucent paint to position

92.text:
and delineate the head on the canvas. This
is particularly noticeable round the jawline

98.text: and also on at the back of the head.

101.text:
The infrared image also showed an interesting
and unusual mottled pattern beneath the paint

109.text:
and we haven't yet worked out what this might
relate to. It could in fact relate to the

113.text:
condition of the painting or it could be something
to do with the lining of the painting.

119.text:
I am very intrigued by the infrared images
and what these strange mottled marbled effects

126.text:
are that we're seeing and I'm hoping that
during our further investigations I will get

132.text:
some answers to those questions.
X-radiography is another very useful scientific

138.text:
imaging technique that conservators use to
again look through a painting and to see things

144.text:
that are not immediately apparent to the naked
eye

147.text:
An x-ray can give us information about the
type of paints used. Certain paints will allow

155.text:
x-rays to pass through them others will impede
the x-ray and because of that we get a particular

160.text:
type, character of contrasted image which
we then interpret to gain information about

167.text:
the artist's technique, materials and indeed
condition.

171.text:
So far I've started to remove the surface
dirt from the painting with small cotton wool

177.text:
swabs dipped into deionised water. There isn't
actually very much dirt on the surface but

183.text:
I need to remove that. I've also almost finished
cleaning the back of the painting with small

189.text:
sponges, which trap the dirt without leaving
any debris behind.

195.text:
Hallas: The painting is an amazing example
of Van Dyck's work, it's got incredible brushwork.

202.text:
The confidence and the ease of which the paint
is applied to the canvas is an indication

208.text:
of the confidence and charisma of the artist,
it really shows through in the portrait itself.

214.text:
Ryder: This is a painting with amazing skill
and mastery. For me, I can't think of

220.text:
a nicer and more elegantly understated self-portrait
to be spending time with.

225.text:
It is extremely skilfully executed and as
a practical person, as a restorer, I really

233.text:
do appreciate what Van Dyck created in this
self-portrait.
